reinforcements.similarity: Both address the critical gap between human-mediated trust and platform-mediated trust. The existing element (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) prescribes priming the digital experience from within the human interaction and designing the platform to echo the call. The new element (Replace the Human Signifier with a Coherent System Image) goes further: it identifies that Susan has NO independent system image of Split Lease at all — she misidentifies it as a real estate brokerage. The new element demands a self-sufficient system image that communicates the platform's identity without any human intermediary.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas never sees the platform mentioned during his call; his trust is entirely with Bryant. New evidence: Susan explicitly misidentifies Split Lease as a 'Real estate Agent' (4:55) — the system image is not merely unprimed, it is absent. Norman's system image principle ('the entire burden of communication is on the system image') extends Kahneman's priming principle: priming helps transfer trust from human to digital, but the digital must have a coherent identity worth transferring TO. Two independent lenses (Kahneman + Norman), two independent calls (Andreas + Susan), both confirm: the human-to-digital handoff is the highest-risk transition in the journey.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the vocabulary mismatch between the user's mental model and the platform's data model. The existing element (Translate Between the Host's Mental Model and the Platform's Data Model) prescribes accepting input in the host's native format (monthly rent) and translating internally. The new element (Map Platform Controls to the Guest's Natural Language) prescribes the identical pattern for guests: accept months and weekday names, translate to night counts internally, and show both vocabularies simultaneously.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas thinks in monthly rent ($2,400/month), not nightly rates ($80/night). New evidence: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months') and weekday names ('Monday to Friday'), not night counts ('30 night minimum'). Both Kahneman's bat-and-ball research and Norman's mapping principle confirm that forced vocabulary translation causes errors and abandonment. This is now validated from BOTH sides of the marketplace — hosts and guests both need the platform to speak their language first.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust verification through structured evidence rather than bare claims. The existing element (Trust Credential Stack: Process Before Promise) prescribes mechanism-before-claim ordering for hosts (credit check before 'payment guaranteed'). The new element (Surface Trust Signifiers That Replace Physical Inspection) prescribes a layered trust system for guests: verified photos, first-night cancellation guarantee, host identity verification — all as structured, discoverable evidence that replaces physical inspection.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Bryant builds Andreas's trust through a process chain (credit check → pre-authorization → guarantee). New evidence: Bryant builds Susan's trust through a substitute chain (no preview → verified photos → first-night cancellation). Both Kahneman's causal chain principle and Norman's signifier/anti-affordance framework confirm that trust is built through discoverable process evidence, not through promises. The host side needs process evidence about tenant quality; the guest side needs process evidence about space quality. Same principle, different verification targets.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address immediate feedback as a trust-maintenance mechanism. The existing element (Instant Acknowledgment on Every Host Input) prescribes sub-100ms visual feedback modeled on Bryant's verbal 'Yep' pattern. The new element (Provide Immediate, Informative Feedback at Every Negotiation Action) extends this to asynchronous interactions: when feedback cannot be instant (proposals, counter-offers), the system must provide predictive timing ('Rita usually responds in 6 hours') and intermediate heartbeat feedback.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Bryant acknowledges every host input in under 500ms ('Yep,' 'Got it,' 'Yup'). New evidence: when the phone call drops for 20 seconds (2:42-3:05), both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?' — trust erodes within seconds of lost feedback. Kahneman's delayed-feedback research maps to synchronous interactions; Norman's planned-feedback principle extends to asynchronous ones. The combined insight: feedback must be instant for synchronous actions AND predictive for asynchronous ones.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address financial display using the user's native vocabulary. The existing element (Single-Sum Financial Display) prescribes one total in the host's native format (monthly rent) before any breakdown. The new element (Natural-Language Duration Mapping) prescribes schedule and duration presets in the guest's vocabulary (months, weekday groups) with a real-time translation summary showing both guest language and platform units.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: Andreas processes pricing as a sequential sum ('Three months. Got it.'). New evidence: Susan and Bryant negotiate duration as '1-2 months' and '5 nights a week' while the platform requires '30 night minimum.' Both elements share the same root principle: present the user's vocabulary first, the platform's vocabulary second. Already validated from the host side (Kahneman lens); now validated from the guest side (Norman lens). This is the third independent confirmation of the vocabulary-first principle across the library.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the need for transparent, structured status communication during the proposal-to-acceptance pipeline. The existing element (Proposal Progress Pipeline) prescribes showing the guest where they are, what happens next, and who acts. The new element (Negotiation Feedback Timeline) prescribes a visual timeline with discrete states (Proposal Sent, Host Reviewing, Host Responded, Your Turn, Agreed) with response-time predictions and intermediate heartbeat feedback.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (Nneka run): after the guest submits a proposal, they enter an anxiety-producing waiting state with no visibility. New evidence (Susan run): Bryant's promise to 'keep you updated' (6:57) is the only signifier Susan receives for what happens next. Both Norman's feedback principle and Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework confirm that asynchronous waiting without status signifiers produces abandonment. The new element adds specific implementation details (response-time predictions, counter-offer diffs, heartbeat intervals) that operationalize the existing principle.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the platform's failure to communicate what Split Lease IS to first-time visitors. The existing element (Schedule-First Listing Cards) prescribes leading listing cards with schedule pattern compatibility rather than property features. The new element (Platform Identity Signifier) prescribes a persistent identity signifier on every page ('Book the nights you need') that communicates the non-continuous model in the guest's vocabulary.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (Nneka run): the listing card information hierarchy should lead with schedule compatibility. New evidence (Susan run): Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55) because no page communicates what the service IS. The new element operates at a higher level — it is not just about listing cards but about every page carrying a system-level identity signifier. The existing element is a component-level implementation of this system-level principle.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the listing card information hierarchy for shared housing. The existing element (Schedule-First Listing Cards) prescribes leading with schedule pattern fit. The new element (Listing Space Composition Signifier) prescribes a three-part label (room type + bathroom + co-occupancy) as the first text element, because Susan's first three questions are about space composition, not schedule.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: schedule compatibility is the primary filter dimension for hybrid workers. New evidence: Susan asks 'full apartment or bedroom?' (0:43), 'bathroom?' (1:08), and 'somebody else there?' (1:20) before any schedule question. For guests evaluating shared housing, space composition precedes schedule in the decision hierarchy. The two elements are complementary: space composition answers 'What am I sharing?' while schedule fit answers 'When can I stay?' Both should be primary listing card elements.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional foundation of first contact. reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (host side): cognitive ease at first touch produces automatic trust in the platform. New evidence (guest side): Susan arrives with prior scam experiences that make cognitive ease insufficient — she needs structured evidence (verified photos, cancellation guarantee) that acknowledges her protective instincts. The combined insight: cognitive ease works as a FOUNDATION, but trust-anxious guests require an additional layer of evidence-based assurance on top of that foundation.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional quality of the active lease phase. journey_emotion_map.rationale: The guest arrives disoriented, not hostile. She needs comprehension relief — the feeling of 'oh, I get it' — within 5 seconds. Clarity prevents the bounce that occurs when the guest cannot form a conceptual model of what the service is.

During search, the guest needs continued clarity (understanding listing cards and schedule patterns) plus emerging agency (configuring filters that match her natural vocabulary). The transition from clarity to agency begins here.

The guest's primary emotional state is protective vigilance driven by prior scam experiences. She needs evidence-based assurance — not warmth, not reassurance, but structured verification that the space is legitimate. Assurance converts vigilance into willingness to proceed.

Susan is assertive and transactional. She does not need guidance; she needs to feel in control of the proposal. Real-time translation of her choices into financial consequences gives her the visibility that produces agency.
During negotiation, agency (I can respond to counter-offers) and assurance (the cancellation guarantee is confirmed as a term) coexist. The guest needs to feel both in control and protected.

At acceptance, the guest has committed money and her friend's travel plans. She needs grounded confidence: clear terms, visible next steps, and the cancellation guarantee restated. Not celebration. Not reassurance. A roadmap.

The guest arrives alone in a new city. Safety is the primary emotional need — the feeling of being guided, protected, and able to exit if necessary. The House Manual, verification checklist, and cancellation banner all serve this emotion.

During the active lease, the guest needs ease (smooth weekly routine, minimal platform friction) and the proxy coordinator needs recognition (acknowledged as a partner in the booking, not an edge case).

arc_conflicts.conflict: The emotional arc for proxy booking creates a dual-track emotional journey. The coordinator (Susan) experiences a different emotional arc than the occupant (friend). Susan's arc: protective vigilance → agency → confidence → recognized. The friend's arc: disorientation → assurance → safety → ease. The platform must serve both arcs simultaneously during the active lease phase.
arc_conflicts.resolution: Role-aware emotional design: the coordinator's notifications and Stays Manager view are tuned to the coordinator's emotional arc (recognition, agency); the occupant's view is tuned to the occupant's arc (safety, ease). Both arcs converge at acceptance (confidence for both) and diverge at move-in (safety for occupant, recognized for coordinator).

emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is internally consistent and phase-appropriate. It follows a clear trajectory: confusion → clarity (discovery), vigilance → assurance (evaluation), assertiveness → agency (proposal/negotiation), commitment → confidence (acceptance), vulnerability → safety (move-in), routine → ease (active lease). The arc is distinct from prior runs: the Kahneman-lens runs emphasized cognitive ease and depletion-aware pacing; this Norman-lens run emphasizes clarity, assurance, and safety as evidence-based emotions rather than feeling-based ones. The two arc types are complementary: cognitive ease is the FOUNDATION (warm surfaces, familiar patterns), while evidence-based assurance is the STRUCTURE (verified photos, cancellation guarantees, chronological House Manuals) built on that foundation.

discovery.note: Strong coverage of the system image problem and identity communication. The Norman lens uniquely identifies that the platform has NO independent system image — Susan misidentifies Split Lease entirely. All five layers contribute elements addressing this gap.

search.note: Strong coverage of natural-language mapping, schedule presets, and space composition signifiers. The Norman lens adds the space composition label (room type + bathroom + co-occupancy) as a new primary listing card element that prior runs did not identify.

listing_evaluation.note: Strongest phase in this run. The Norman lens contributes the layered trust verification stack, the no-preview policy as a signified anti-affordance, and the first-night cancellation guarantee as a phase-adaptive affordance — none of which existed in the library.

proposal_creation.note: Strong coverage including the entirely new proxy booking pattern. The Norman lens adds natural-language duration/schedule selectors and proxy role differentiation.

negotiation.note: Strong coverage of the negotiation feedback timeline and cancellation guarantee as a negotiation term. The Norman lens adds specific feedback timing requirements (heartbeat notifications, counter-offer diffs).

acceptance.note: Strong coverage of the acceptance-to-move-in transition. The Norman lens adds the 'What happens next' timeline and the cancellation guarantee restatement at the moment of commitment.

move_in.note: Previously the weakest phase in the library. This run significantly strengthens move-in coverage with the chronological House Manual, verification checklist, persistent cancellation banner, and move-in emotional design. This is the Norman lens's most distinctive contribution.

active_lease.note: Moderate coverage focusing on proxy booking coordination, House Manual reference mode, and routine notification pacing. The existing library (Nneka run) already has strong active_lease coverage through the Stays Manager, date change tool, and micro-review elements. This run extends it with proxy role management and move-in verification as a longitudinal trust record.
